author: Lawrent34

description.text:
Having finally gotten my printer to produce clean prints, I decided it was time to celebrate, which means making the obligatory shot glass :-)
I decided I wanted something reprap related, so I designed a shot glass in the shape of a hollowed out, tapered reprap teardrop.

Print, fill with your favorite alcohol, drink.
Actually, unless you coat it with food grade urethane first, I wouldn't suggest using it.
The walls are just a fraction more than 2mm thick, so I printed it with 2 extra shells, and an extrusion width of 0.424, which results in a filament spacing of 0.333, and produces a solid wall with no center gap.

comments.text: Natureworks PLA is supposedly FDA approved for food contact and storage. Not sure if that stands after pigments are added and it's extruded into filament.
comments.author: NETio

comments.text: Short-term testing shows that they hold alcohol, while long-term testing shows a major design flaw - all the alcohol leaks out of the top, and they need repeated refilling.

comments.author: MKotsamanes

comments.text:
Thingiverse is based on taking existing works making changes and mixing it with other designs to make new or better designs. When the copyright is respected this is how the system is supposed to work.
I have designs that are based on others works, fixing things I thought they missed or things that didn’t quite work with my printer set-up. I didn’t just complain that they should fix it for me. Also when I did fix it myself I posted it respecting their copyright and without asking for a gold star or a cookie for my efforts.
With my printer set-up and choice of materials I was able to assemble the unit and other people have been able to assemble it also. Did I have to put in some effort to do assemble it? Sure, about 10-15 minutes worth. Was it “basically useless” and required a complete redesign? No, it served the purpose I needed it too. I wanted a tighter fit to require less glue on the edges that might affect the look when light from inside.
My job was finished maybe you didn’t see the pictures above. I needed one print for a gift, I designed it, printed it, assembled it and gave it away. My job isn’t making and posting designs for free on Thingiverse that work with everyone’s printer and their ability to use some sandpaper or a nail file.
You thought the design was cool enough to print a copy for yourself. You had some difficulty assembling it and made some changes to the design and now have a “better” design, please accept this gold star for your efforts. You chose not to post your “improved” design (or even details and pictures on how you “improved” it) for everyone to benefit from and possibly find an even better way of doing it (or post rude comments on your design) that’s your choice.

title: Wanhao Duplicator Screen and button box

description.text:
Hi everyone.
After putting a fourth motherboard in my Makerbot Replicator 1... I now also had to replace the screen and buttons.
I bought a set from Wanhao (for the duplicator 4)... which works fine with a Replicator style mightyboard, but doesn't fit the housing.
So I created a custom box for the parts that fits on the front of my Replicator 1.
I used a reamer to make the holes for the bolts fit perfectly and some sanding paper on the red pieces (making the design perfect would have taken longer).
The Washers you either print as a tube (no fill/bottom/top), or drill a hole through em (4mm long washers for the screen, 7mm for the buttons).
The bolts n nuts were just 8 15mm long 3mm wide ones from a local hardware store.

This ball bearing uses 6 marbles that are 16 mm in diameter. I got a bag of 50 marbles for a dollar at Toys R Us. This is in three pieces (two of the cage piece, and one shaft piece). I managed to put the thing together, including marbles. I'm not a mechanical engineer, and the movement is a bit rough, and catches a little in places. If you drive it with a cordless drill, it rattles because things aren't all perfectly aligned. But it does rotate. Here's a little video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ie1mtN5CR90 After making the video, I took it apart and sanded the inside surfaces that touch the marbles, and the motion became a lot smoother. I used the cordless drill to help sand the surfaces on the axle.

Printer:

Micro M3D

Resolution:

Low

Infill:

Yes, on the shaft

Notes: I'm using the Micro-M3D with non-M3D filament (using cheat code "PUB"). What I've found is that it's good to put skinny 5mm-long legs under things to make raft removal easier. My legs are little cones, 1 mm wide at the bottom and 0.1mm wide at the top, that just touch the bottom surface of the object. So they pop off when I'm removing the supports, and I get a clean bottom surface. I used the printer's highest setting for infill on the axle, because if you don't, and then you squeeze it in the chuck of your cordless drill, it gets a bit crunched and I'm pretty sure it becomes weaker as a result.
Designed in OpenSCAD I really love OpenSCAD but I kinda wish somebody would create a GUI for it that looks like the TinkerCad website.

remixed_from.author: pyrophreek
remixed_from.title: Printing in Polyurethane Rubber using Fenner Drives' Eagle Orange

description.text: Needed a heating pad for an experiment in my lab, and the quotes for custom made equipment were out of our budget.  So I built one myself.

1) Select your controller and power supply. I used the following so STLs will work for these: Temperature controller:
http://www.amazon.com/Digital-Display-Temperature-Controller-Great/dp/B002PIM3R8/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1374113319&sr=8-1&keywords=temperature+controller+PID Power Supply:
http://www.amazon.com/Amico-Switching-Power-Supply-Adapter/dp/B008SNZD08/ref=sr_1_3?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1369688714&sr=1-3&keywords=24V+power+supply Rear Power Socket:
http://www.amazon.com/Amico-IEC320-Module-Switch-Socket/dp/B0050HH70E/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1371500604&sr=8-3&keywords=IEC+320+socket Plugs and transistor and voltage regulator were purchased from Radio Shack. Feet were printed in polyurethane rubber, and resulted in a very nice solid and vibration resistant case. Bottom, top and side panels were cut from 1/4 in plywood and screwed into the appropriate holes. Countersunk guide holes were used to improve appearance and finish. Heating pad was constructed from Kapton Tape and cork board with a PT100 surface mount sensor from Digikey and a coil of NiChrome wire from Ultimachine:
https://ultimachine.com/content/31-awg-nichrome-wire-0

title: 6 Hole Flute
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: It works! http://youtu.be/S-z3_xKU77Y While working with Cymon (who doesn't have a MakerBot) and NYCDESIGNER to try and get Cymon's Recorder design to work http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11796 I decided I needed a little more SCIENCE! So I wrote a parametric OpenSCAD script based on the Whistle/Flute from http://www.ggwhistles.com/howto/ that allows you to experiment with different hole placement, size, window and lip angles, etc. This flute is much simpler then a recorder (and not nearly as pretty as Cymon's) but it is able to play 6 notes quite clearly and loudly. Now if only I knew how to play the flute... This is still a work in progress because I think I can get the mouthpiece/lip to print a little easier. It's kind of fiddly to get it just right.

Print bottom, middle, and top and then glue them together.  Make sure it's air tight.  Then slide on the mouthpiece.  You may need to carefully file the lip to make it nice and sharp and flat.
Alternatively, you can print top1 and glue it to middle and bottom.  Then you have a body and can experiment with top2 and mouthpiece options.  Use the joint_ring to temporarily join top1 and top2 together while you experiment.
Don't print assembly_solid unless you have a giant printer with support.  :)

title: Eames Molded Plywood Coffee Table
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: "Roger, if you had your way, I would be stranded in some paperweight with my legs stuck in the air." -Joan Holloway Get your MCM on with a 1:16 scale Eames Molded Plywood Coffee Table! This is Thing 05 in the Madiverse (Mad Men + Thingiverse) http://bit.ly/madiverse!

• Print one of each file, you will need outside support material for the table top:

  • Eames_Molded_Plywood_Table_Legs_Plate.stl

  • Eames_Molded_Plywood_Table_Top.stl

  • File and/or sand the legs to create smooth edges then use CA/super glue to attach them together as shown.

  • The full-size table comes in several finishes: walnut, cherry, ash or black. If you don't have the correct color filament, use paint or permanent markers to color the finished prints before proceeding.

  • Glue legs to center of bottom of top using CA glue.

title: Atomic Force Microscope Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A basic model of how an atomic force microscope or scanning-tunneling microscope works to "see" atoms and molecules. Slide the scaffold piece of the frame and the tip will rise and fall to feel out the surface. You can modify the surface with different features such as steps or islands. It simplifies how AFM and STM work but gets the basic idea across of how to map out a surface which is too small to see with visible light.
Eventually I would like to cover the surface so my students could map out what the surface looks like my measuring the change in height of the tip as they "scan" the surface, as well as make other surface structures that could be mapped out.

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

This model helps to continue the discussion that is brought about when discussing the history of the atom. Once students understand how we learned about the structure of the atom, it is important to discuss current technologies that teach us about atoms. The atomic force microscope (AFM) is one of these technologies.
Objectives:
Students will be able to describe how atomic force/ scanning-tunneling microscopy is used to create an image of an atomic surface.
Students will be able to translate change in height data from the tip into a drawing of the surface profile
Students will be able to predict changes in height based on added features to the surface such as islands, steps, and holes.

Discuss why light microscopes cannot be used to see atoms and molecules.
Describe how to slide the scaffold over the surface so the tip rises and falls.
Cover the surface so the students cannot see it and let the students figure out and discuss how such a technique can be used to recreate what an atomic surface looks like, thereby modeling how we can "see" an atomic surface with an AFM.
Have students graph the height of the tip vs position in the x and y direction and discuss how the graph shows a profile of the surface. By drawing multiple graphs as the students move the tip across the surface, they can reconstruct a 3D image from 3D slices. This is how AFM and STM works.

AFM Model
Graph Paper
Floder or cardboard to block view of the models surface

First constructed by Albert E. Bosman in 1942. It has been proven that the total surface area of a 2D Pythagorean tree is finite, by bounding so is the volume of this 3D pythagorean tree.

description.text: BotBot can print anything he can see - he has a "Level 2 Integraded 3D scanner" embedded to his head. His main-supporting frame hides a full 3D printer. BotBot has also rocket-booster-boots so he can quickly fly to a location where 3D printing help is needed most. His mission in life is to help other robots and bot operators by supplying parts for them. In the pictures you can see how BotBot helped Bobblehead Bob by printing some spare pintacks for Bob. Should BotBot ever malfunction himself, other bots can always use that integraded operating panel with LCD-display and cursor keys in BotBot's chest to print spare parts for BotBot himself. Thus BotBot can not only repair other bots but BotBot can be used to repair himself :) BotBot uses slightly modified pintacs from "Toy-robot-toolkit" and BotBot would like to thank the creator of that toolkit and Bobblehead Bob for great inspiration - thanks Tony ! BotBot was modeled partially with Alibre Design and partially with Openscad and it was printed with Makerbot Cupcake CNC printer in red/white theme. title: Atomic Orbital Collection
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a set of atomic orbitals. The basic design was adapted from BlendeLabor's probability shapes. The files include plans for all of the s, p, d, and f orbitals as well as a connector which can be used to hold all three p orbitals together. The orbitals are great models for showing students what the orbitals look like in three dimensions. They can also be used to show the geometry in bonding, especially when discussing pi and sigma bonds, using the combined p orbitals.
This project contains all of the orbitals that I have made in one place. The orbitals can be found  as operate files on Thingiverse as well.

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

Hollow-5%

Notes: Rafts should be used to help stabilize the orbitals as they print. Supports are not needed. Printing the orbitals with 0 infill works well. If you would like them to make them a little sturdier 5% also works. A little hot glue also helps to keep the orbital connections together.
NGSS CCSS

Preparation:
Students should already be familiar with the concept of probability densities. They should also know that electrons behave as waves and therefore we cannot know their exact positions. The idea of what an orbital is should already have been presented. Objectives:
Students will be able to describe the three-dimensional shapes of atomic orbitals. Students will be able to describe the various ways orbitals can line up in order to form single, double, and triple covalent bonds.

These models are designed to be used as manipulatives to help students understand the three-dimensional shapes of the atomic orbitals. They can be introduced in a variety of ways so there is no one specific activity they are designed for. I have found that I have often reached for them in class whenever I reference the orbitals, types of bonding, and relative reactivity of bonds. They have also been very useful in upper level chemistry classes when describing sigma and pi bonds, as well as hybridization. They can also be used in combination with my hybrid orbital models:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1239504
No other materials needed besides the models.

description.text: This is an old version, link to latest: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1554635 This is my design of a class 250 FPV quadcopter. I am using the DYS BE1806 motors, and It works great. It can also fit 2204 size motors. Fits 5 inch props, not 6 inch. You shouldn't need 6 inch props anyway because of this frame's lightweightness. I am using the Turnigy nano-tech 1500mah battery (pictured) and also the Turnigy 1800mah battery. The front has a mount for a Mobius Actioncam, great for FPV and HD video shooting. The frame has a sturdy design, with the middle and top plates having raised edges so they don't bend. The arms fold inwards for easy storage and decreases chance of arms breaking. So far, I have only broke one arm, and I probably would have broken several more if it wasn't for this feature. M3 Nylon hardware is used in most places for lightweightness, although M3 metal should work also. The control board used is a custom MultiWii board I designed using Eagle and made using toner-transfer techniques and PCB etchant. Will also fit any other board with 30-35mm hole spacing. I am not using a standard power distribution board, I just soldered the wires to brass strips and glued them to the plate. (very ameturish, but works!) Landing gear is made from a M3x30mm screw put through the hole in the arm and a piece of brass tubing on the other side glued together. This works surprisingly well and is very durable. Designed in OpenSCAD For more information about this design and my other projects, check out my website at http://netzero.solarlogic.net/andrew/

title: AirArm - Articulated Scroll Saw Air Blower

description.text: A friend of mine was complaining that the static air blower on his Ryobi scroll saw was an annoyance, making it more difficult than it should be to use. He'd seen newer scroll saws with articulated air blower arms, and wanted to know if it was possible to retrofit his with one. This project is the result. It uses the ball and socket joints from Giuseppe Finizia's PCB Workstation with Articulated Arms, and adds a base plate and end effector to hold a standard sized piece of aquarium tubing. The base plate and end effector are implemented in OpenSCAD, and can be edited to fit different applications (base size, air line diameter, etc). Both components import parts of the "BS_Joint.stl" file from Giuseppe's PCB Workstation, so changes to the base and end won't effect their compatibility with existing printed joints. If you want to modify the SCAD files, it may be easier to checkout the source from the project's GitHub page.

Customize the SCAD files for the base and end as needed, then print them both along with enough of "BS_Joint.stl" to get the desired length.
Attach the base to a stationary part of the saw (I used 3M double sided tape), and fit the air line into the end of the arm. If the saw or tool doesn't have a built-in air system, you can use a standard aquarium pump.
If the arm moves around while the tool is in operation, you can tighten up the individual ball and socket joints by using a layer or two of tape or shrink tubing on each ball.

title: VR stereo viewer bracket for iPhone5

description.text: My smart phone VR Viewer that I bought on eBay has a cavity that fits dimensions up to 14mm x 80mm x 150mm - and employs suction cups to 'suspend' phones smaller than that dimension in the center of the viewing area. They don't work... at all. So, I made this bracket which holds my iPhone5s perfectly centered, with or without it's sleeve on! The two detents were added so that the volume buttons wouldn't get activated while in use. Enjoy! Feel free to check out my other designs which are as diverse as they are many: http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

author: frednet

description.text:
My Immersion Vortex had taken a pretty good beating lately, and because of it the flight controller was acting up weird (not saving settings at all) and the video transmitter wasn't staying on channel which rendered it virtually useless for FPV. Since I had my other quads going my vortex pretty much turned into a paperweight. What a shame I thought, I really liked the motor and ESCs from it but hated that I couldn't get the FC and VTX to work right. Then I had a brain child! Why not use the motors and ESCs with the arms to make a small X layout quad? So I used my very elementary 3D modeling skills to design and print up a little center frame to hold the old vortex arms. I'll call it the Vort-X...
I cut down the vortex arms by about 15mm (just past the hole that the original arm joint mounted on). Turned out to be 190mm, fits perfectly with 5" props.
This was my first crack at designing something like this and I am by no means a 3D modeler, so the design could have been a little nicer. Everything seemed to fit together great though!
Printed in black ABS, 50% infill with support. You will need to drill/cut holes in the back of the top cover to see the lights and push the button to change channel on your VTX. I am using a Fatshark 700tvl camera, I think that probably all that is going to fit but I am sure you can fit others if you are creative.
Held together with 8ea M3X25mm socket head screws with lock nuts. Also, 4 M3X5mm button head screws to hold the cover on.

description.text: This is a fun little mechanical gadget.  I think it is called a fast return actuator.  Turn the crank clockwise and the bird swings back and forth with a very satisfying pecking motion.  I made something similar out of wood years ago, pretty fun to be able to draw it in sketchup and print it out.

Print one of each part. I print the stand, washers and bird using raftless printing configured basically how they describe on the makerbot wiki (http://wiki.makerbot.com/thingomatic-doc:raftless). The modifications I made are: 1) I changed the Object First Layer Feed Rate Infill Multiplier (ratio) to be 0.5 2) I change the Object First Layer Feed Rate Permieter Multiplier (ratio) to 0.5 3) I changed the Object First Layer Flow Rate Multiplier (ratio) to 0.9 4) I disabled the Outline feature and generally delete the lines of gCode that do the warm up extrusion. I print the washers using a raft because I think the smooth finish it leaves on one side is nice. These are small enough that I think you could get away with printing them raftlessly. The washers slide onto the shafts with a little pressure. The whole thing assembles for me with no extrenal parts.

description.text: The Eiger is a 3,970-metre (13,020 ft) mountain of the Bernese Alps, overlooking Grindelwald and Lauterbrunnen in the Bernese Oberland, just north of the main watershed and border with Valais. It is the easternmost peak of a ridge crest that extends across the Mönch to the Jungfrau at 4,158 m (13,642 ft), constituting one of the most emblematic sights of the Swiss Alps. While the northern side of the mountain rises more than 3,000 m (10,000 ft) above the two valleys of Grindelwald and Lauterbrunnen, the southern side faces the large glaciers of the Jungfrau-Aletsch area, the most glaciated region in the Alps. The most notable feature of the Eiger is its 1,800-metre-high (5,900 ft) north face of rock and ice, named Eigerwand or Nordwand, which is the biggest north face in the Alps. This huge face towers the resort of Kleine Scheidegg at its base, on the homonymous pass connecting the two valleys.

Inspired by the excellent tutorial by Shapespeare. 1 Arc-Second (30m) Digital Elevation Model data was sourced from: http://www.viewfinderpanoramas.org/Coverage%20map%20viewfinderpanoramas_org1.htm Embossing created with the Microsoft 3D Builder app.

Here is one of the the ultimate functional designs. Here is a battery clip for the Ryobi One batteries that gets 18V out wherever you need it. Couple that with the 5v USB regulator you can purchase from Amazon for a few bucks (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00CPYYAFA?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s01)
or a variable power and current supply module (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00OZGVL4O?keywords=adjustable%20power%20regulator&qid=1449899295&ref_=sr_1_4&sr=8-4)
and you've got one rechargable and portable power supply for all of your needs. Most laptops run at around that voltage as well so with the right regulator and plug assembly, you could have a never ending source for your laptop or tablet power. I put pigtails on mine so I can change what I use it for. My current applications are 1. attch the variable voltage module and set it for 7.2 volts, thorow it in a backpack and use it to power my Sony a55 digital camera for a yet untertermined period of time and I also use it with the USB charger cable to power my iPhone when it is on a tripipod as a great video recorder (see my printable iPhone tripod mount)

Wiring When completed, you may need to clean out the holes for the wire. Use some solid copper hobby wire roughly 20 gauge (.8 ~ .9 mm). Strip back about 30mm / 1.25 inch of insulation, feed it in the top hole, loop it through the bottom, pull it tight and twist togethher. Notice the wire in the macro photo above. I then stripped back the other end and soldered on my pigtail wires. I then wrapped athe entire clip in black electrical tape to insulate the exposed copper. Not the prettiest job I've done but it is one of the more functional.

title: Ultimate 38mm Rotating Spool Holder - MakerBot Replicator 2

description.text:
Quickly change 38mm filament spools using this amazing free spinning spool holder. The holder rotates freely to reduce friction and ensure smooth prints. Convenient slots enable you to quickly secure the spool using a filament clip. As a bonus, you don't lose filament clips. Long (5lb spool) and short (2.2lb spool) 38mm spool holders are available. The long version supports both 5lb and 2.2lb spools. Both 1.75mm and 3.0mm filament clips are part of this project. Video of the spool holder in operation: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KPtGQ4V8H-0
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ee25BwZchII This spool holder requires a bolt and lock nut commonly available at most hardware stores. The cost is usually less than 40 cents.

Requirements: 5/16" x 3.5" hex head bolt (short 2.2lb spool holder), 5/16" x 5.5" hex head bolt (long 5lb spool holder), 5/16" lock nut, 1/2" socket, and printed parts
  • Print parts without support or raft
  • Snap off supports from the Spool Holder Mount
  • Insert bolt in the back of the Spool Holder Mount until flush
  • Slide the Spool Holder onto Spool Holder Mount bolt
  • If the Spool Holder doesn't rotate freely run the bolt in and out to wear down imperfections. You can also try 300-600 grit sandpaper on the smooth section of the bolt.
  • Attach the lock nut to the bolt with a 1/2" socket
  • Tighten the lock nut so that the Spool Holder still spins freely
  • Attach new Spool Holder to back of MakerBot Replicator 2 and enjoy!

title: Improved Dome for Flashforge Creator Pro

description.text:
(for a handle for this dome please see thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2325371) (note: more information about the filament guide tube holder I use with this dome can be found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1167693 ) Update (Jan 2017) FlashForge seems to ship the 2016 models with a new dome that is made of a single piece. This is an improvement over the older version which as made from flat sheets of clear plastic attached by screws. However, the new dome still use the same T shape cut in the back for the filament tubes. The Makerbot dome described here has a better tube path IMO since the tube rise inside without any cut in the back of the dome. Update (Feb 2016): [email protected] reported that this dome worked also with the FlashForge Creator Wooden: "I just needed to trim down my filament guide tubes". This thing describes an improved dome for Flashforge Creator Pro 3D printer. This dome has a few advantages over the stock one.
  • Better filament guide path that moves freely.
  • Better heat enclosure. The opening is at the bottom so the heat is captured in the dome and draft cannot get in.
  • Better construction. This is a one piece dome as opposed to the flimsy stock dome.
  • Looks much better.
    • You can purchase MakerBot Replicator 2X Acrylic Dome Cover here: http://store.makerbot.com/parts-accessories/replicator-2-2x/x1-rep2x-top-enclosure.html . The Makerbot dome has a different shape at the bottom so it doesn't fit into the opening of the Flashforge case. To held it in place I used two rubber coated magnets from Amazon CMS Magnetics® 9 lb Holding Power Neodymium Magnetic Hook Rubber Coated. Pack of 2 http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IGHBD7I but they are not required and the dome stays in place without them. When placing the magnets, to avoid a high impact on the acrylic dome, place the magnets on their side and then turn them slowly until their surface is in full contact with the dome. I am also using a modified filament tube holder at the back of the case, it is slanted and moves the feeding point closer to the center of the spool. You can find it's 3D model in my account here as well.

comments.text: maybe you are using a different layer height or nozzle size?  I was using .4mm nozzle and .3mm layer height. Sometimes with a larger/smaller layer height, a thin-walled thing will either print too many layers or print too few and essentially be invisible. Maybe try switching to .3mm resolution if you haven't already and see if that helps. (I know that doesn't make much sense because it should be the nozzle size that is the thing actually making the difference, but also I know that this sometimes does help anyway!) Let me know, I'm curious to see if that works and maybe can think of something else to try if not.

description.text:
I liked much a design lamp posted by dan3088
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:319339 When printed realized that solid metal design becoming very weak when printed in ABS. And some nicer parts can be done. Started from legs only. But peace by peace ALL parts were redesigned and replaced (even main body-rail was changed with a different wire-path to fit real 220V cable for LED bulb).
I printed all lamp parts in 2 colors (0.8 mm external slices in natural white and internal part in dark grey). All spacers and nuts are in light blue. All materials are ABS from 3D Prima.

While printing consider special use of support options. lamp_body_NEW1.stl - NO, but put manually supports for the bottom space only, it takes you 2 minutes (if automatic supports added, you will have problems to fit the electric cable)
lamp back leg NEW1.stl - YES (grey color)
lamp back leg NEW1.stl - YES (grey color)
ER11A_nut_mother_diam_21_outside.stl (YES)
ER11A_nut_father_diam_21_outside.stl (YES) Other files are optimized for printing WITHOUT supports:
lamp_shade_NEW1_back.stl
lamp_shade_NEW1_front.stl
led_holder_G9socket_NEW1.stl
lamp_spine_NEW1.stl
lamp_spacers_NEW1.stl

The special adapter is created to hold standard G9 electro socket with 220 V bulb(led_holder_G9socket_NEW1.stl). The LED 20W bulb used and hopefully will be not too hot in operation. See post-printing images.

description.header: Two assembly zips includes all needed for printing
description.text:
Aviation_inspired_desk_lamp NEW1 dual color.zip - dual color
Aviation_inspired_desk_lamp NEW1 mono color.zip - single color
GCODE - Flashforge 3D Dreamer.zip - all print files (dual color) for specific 3D printer. Right extruder (grey ABS) - supports and internal layers. Left extruder (white ABS) - rafts and external layers. Mono color models printed always by right extruder.

• curved front legs are optional (lamp_front_leg_NEW1_curved.stl( and can replace straight leg design.
  • lamp shade: full model is provided in file lamp_shade_NEW1.stl, but no need to print. to be printed in 2 parts (lamp_shade_NEW1_back.stl, lamp_shade_NEW1_front.stl) with no supports.
    • p.s. particular thanks to dan3088 (http://www.thingiverse.com/dan3088/about), who put that marvelous design

Flashforge 3D Dreamer (dual extruder)

Yes

Yes

standard 0.2mm

15% line

Assembly plans Refer to assembly image (and .stl) for details. Basically all parts can be just assembled or glued with aceton. You will also need 2 nuts 3mm diameter to mount lamp shade and back spacer. Lamp shade finishing to make more light, you can color the lamp's shade internally with a reflecting spray-color.
It almost doubled the light reflection for my 20W LED lamp. I used brass acrylic spray. Consider to cover the full model with plastic to avoid unnecessary sanding later. 2 layers of spray are enough Fitting LED with standard G9 socket (special adapter designed to fit into the lamp shade)

remixed_from.author: HunterGreen
remixed_from.title: Star Wars Death Star Turret for X-Wing game

description.text:
This is a remix of a Death Star Laser turret for the Star Wars X-Wing miniatures game. It is not intended to be an accurate prop replica. I sliced the existing file into 3 parts and modified them so the turret can rotate and the guns can elevate. The base is hollow and the guns have been slimmed up. The assembly is entirely snap together. The STL file includes an assembly of all three parts. They are Cura scaled and oriented for printing. If desired they can be split apart and printed separately, or independently deleted from the assembly. Cura allows you to break the assembly apart, delete what you do not want, and save off the individual parts if you can't load an STL file into a modeling editor. The hollow base allows for the future idea of inserting a destroyed turret base inside.
Update: 12/13/15 - The future has arrived. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1198080 will take you to a destroyed base insert for this print. See the image uploaded above for a preview. UPDATE: 5/29/2017 STL files that include a simple short barrel version of the guns and the destroyed base insert with slightly more prominent surface detail have been added to the download files. They are interchangeable with the previous parts. Note: The gun barrels are in the orientation they are intended to be when inserted into the turret. They could be printed vertically if you keep track of that orientation. The barrels are closer to the bottom of the pivot than they are to the top so as to be more flat against the top of the rotation post.

Printer:

Rigidbot Big

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20% - 30%

Notes: A 5 to 10 line brim will help the small surface area of the first layer stick to the bed. A 0.8 mm shell and top and bottom surfaces seems to work well. A good part cooling fan greatly helps in bridging across the support material. One assembly prints in around 2 - 2.5 hours. It is highly recommended that you use calibrated filament to print this assembly for best results. I use the filament calibration system found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301. Guarantees a precise assembly.
Clean up Removal of the support material and possibly some fine hairs between the parts will require some cleanup before assembly. Should not take more than about 10 min of effort.

title: Rotating Trivet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: DO NOT PRINT WITH ABS OR PLA, HIGH TEMP FILAMENT IS A MUST. This trivet was created by Adam Bujnowski, Alex Kinney, and Mark Traverso as part of Virginia Tech's Mechanical Engineering class in additive manufacturing. Eastman chemical supplied the material for prototyping, this design is based on their amphora line of filament, which is PETG based. Colorfabb-XT and Taulman n-Vent are the amphora filaments available at this time. It is recommended that this design be printed with Amphora. Amphora has a higher melt temp than abs and pla and is crucial to the trivet working properly. Other PET based filament should also work but have not been tested. This trivet will work with most cookware at temperatures up to 110 degrees C. Try not to use the trivet with cookware at higher temps, eventually this will melt. This trivet was designed using heat transfer properties of truss based unit cell fins. It is recommend that this be printed face down meaning that the fins will be the top layer when printing. Using a heated bed in this orientation seems to provide a better heat resistance to the top. Thank you for looking and please share your results. Also picture is show to what happens if you use to hot of a pan.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: PET based filaments work well, honeycomb infill works well, print with a minimum of three shells. Larger ring was printed with mass portal pharaoh, other prints were better on printrbot. Turn support off for bridging if using amphora, Amphora is very good at bridging so no need for support there. Use pillar support for the sliding joint support, if using another type will be hard to remove support. I learned that the hard way.

Thank you to Dr. Chris Williams for giving us an opportunity learn about AM and teach a fun class. For anyone thinking about taking his class (ME 4644 and ME 5644) or coming to VT, do it.
A big thank you to Eastman Chemical Company for giving us an opportunity to showcase a design with your product. Existing trivets are generally a flat piece of material with simple geometry that doesn’t optimize heat transfer and convection. Another issue is that they are usually large and bulky and difficult to store within the kitchen. These two principles are the main thoughts that lead to the idea of a 3D printed solution. With additive manufacturing, complex geometry can optimize heat transfer, customized designs can be added for each customer, and the trivet can be created within the confines of the customers own home. The team decided to take on the challenge of finding a combination of design, material, and printer properties to create a viable product which will perform better than existing trivets in all aspects. After research and comparison, the material chosen to be used was Amphora developed by Eastman Chemical Company. A key property of this material is the high melting and deflection temperature, which is essential to this product. This was found to be higher than any other usual material used in the 3D printing industry. The printer that was chosen was the Mass Portal extrusion printer due to availability. With the printer and material chosen, concept generation and selection began.
Many concepts with unique ideas were all considered and compared against each other, which came to the final solution of a semi-circle design. This semicircle design consists of a sliding joint around the circumference of three separate sections, which allows the trivet to expand in size. On the top of this design, there are channels cut into the pieces to allow for airflow underneath the pot, which will promote convective heat transfer from the pot. On the underside, there are complex fins added which will help to evenly disperse heat throughout the trivet and optimizing overall heat transfer of the whole system. After the final design was complete, the next step was prototyping and testing.
With the parts that were printed, a thermal analysis was conducted using simulation software. The analysis showed that our trivet had a lower temperature in contact with the counter surface than current trivets by approximately 13 C, thus proving our trivet actually performs more efficiently than existing trivets. Along with the simulation, the team wanted to test the piece in an actual application. Hot pots of boiling water, as well as baking sheets, were placed on the trivet with complete success. No deformation or melting of the trivet occurred with these usual applications. A failure analysis was also conducted to see at what point the trivet would fail, so the team tested the trivet in a worst case scenario by placing an empty pan at max temperature on the trivet. This caused severe melting, warping, and also caused the trivet to stick to the bottom of the pan and require scraping to remove it. With the failure of the part, the team recommends that it only be used for pots of boiling water, light cooking, and pans used for baking since most of these uses result in contact temperatures less than 110°C. This will keep the user safe, as well as the counter or tabletop the trivet is resting on safe also.

title: Xmas treetop Deathstar - laser cutter pattern
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made a Christmas card called "family star wars" where a star wars fanboy kept replacing a his sisters rainbow unicorn star on the xmas tree with a deathstar, then I thought, hey I could actually make one of those on the laser cutter at the hackerspace and I set about making the design.
After a few trial runs you now have the latest iteration.

Printer:

Laser Cutter

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: There is a lot of etching because of the hatching which was exploded so it was accepted by our laser cutter. Make sure the cut outs are there for the mounts (4 pairs) these are the only cuts inside the deathstar's outer circle cut. The mounts have a 3mm hole on them so a piece of fencing wire can be threaded through for extra support. Check the order of the etches/ cuts
Do all etching first then cut the small items that may blow out and collect before doing the outer cuts out out the deathstar last. I found it best to sand the laser cut burn off the end of the mounts before glueing in place (the rectangle black /brown marks are visually distracting and not at all like the deathstar's patterns).
I have now sured up the mounting as I had the thin mounts squash when in my back pack

description.text:
Minimal Setup for the Emax Nighthawk 280. The idea is pretty simple, keep the battery as close to the Center of Gravity as possible. So I created the spacers so I could place my PDB & Flight Controller in between the bottom plate and center plate. That was great, but then getting the camera strapped down was a major pain... So I had to design I designed a new top plate that was shorter and could provide protection to the camera, and while doing that I created two versions... One without a GoPro/Xiaomi Yi and one With. The camera mount is designed for the HS1177 Camera (Commonly referred to as a 25x25mm fpv camera). You can use the stock metal frame too (maybe) but I don't know where it'd face and it may be unprotected. Don't have a 3D Printer? Support me and buy through Shapeways:
https://www.shapeways.com/shops/tenfpv

title: Stratux Nano SDR dual case with fan antennas mount on the end

description.text: Edit: This case has been superseded by the squared off slim case, I highly recommend it over this older design. Edit: April 13 Use this revised version instead. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1489378 Edit: February 11. Increased overall length 2mm to fit the popular VK-172 GPS. New version of the Nooelec RTL-SDR means a new smaller case. This version comes in several flavors depending on how many antennas you want to attach and if you want holes for suction cups or not. There are two versions of the base base. The two versions have hole(s) for an MCX-SMA bulkhead adapter. One has a single hole and the second has two holes. All versions of this case have minimal passive vents and have a cutout for a 30x30x10mm fan. All tops have mounts for a GPS/AHRS. RY835AI There are two tops, the only differences are if it has holes for suction cups or not. Suction cup version have 3 6.4mm (1/4") holes in the top for you to insert some suction cups. I got some suction cups with metal hooks at a local hardware store. They just need to have a mushroom head on the back with the thin part being 1/4". I use M3 cap head screws but #4 screws would work just fine. Start by drilling them top case holes to allow the hardware to slide in and then gently screw the screws into the base. https://www.shapeways.com/shops/rtd If you like this design and want to thank me my paypal address is [email protected] I can also do any customization.

The RamenSpooner, or Spooner, is a lid designed for instant noodle soups.  There are several versions for different spoon types and sizes.  After you add hot water to your soup, you place this lid on top of the soup and then place your spoon on top of the lid to help seal the lid and hold the spoon in place.  This helps make a perfect soup every time, and makes for easy carrying of soup to your couch or gaming chair without dropping spoon.

author: Javogongora

title: BananaPi basic case with battery and wall mount

description.text:
I use this BananaPi (m1) as a headless server mounted under my desk. Adding space for a couple inexpensive 18650 batteries takes advantage of the built in charger to provide a handy little UPS for it. The eBay special batteries are marked 6000mah, but are really only 1800s (do your reading when buying, stickers are cheap and lots of cells out there are mislabeled). Since I run this machine headless (only USB for power and Ethernet for access connected) I still get 4 hours of run time on battery. For assembly I used:
  • 4x M3x5 self tapping screws to hold the bpi.
  • 2x M3x8 self tapping screws for the battery pack bar
  • 4x M3x16 bolts to hold to two halves together (after threading the holes in the bottom with a 3mm tap).

comments.text: Awsome work m8, thanks for sharing, ive been looking for something like this for my home automation server.

description.text:
Unenthusiastic Moose Ornament.

remixed_from.title: Stratux case long version dual RTL

description.text: Edit: This case has been superseded by the squared off slim case, I highly recommend it over this older design. Updated April 17 by request I have made a few changes to fit Dan Murrays high gain antennas. The overall length will also now accommodate a VK-172. Look for the files marked new. Single band version of my notched case for the new Nano RTL-SDR. This will actually hold two Nano SDR's the only difference between it and the dual models is that they have to be thicker to provide clearance for the larger GPS. Reduced thickness and added many more vents for passive ventilation. Still has provisions for a GPS but it need to be a smaller 30.5x30.5mm footprint. These are very common in the Multirotor world. Available as a Notched or End SMA mount antenna and with or without 6.4mm (1/4") suction cup holes. I got some suction cups with metal hooks at a local hardware store. They just need to have a mushroom head on the back with the thin part being 1/4". I use M3 cap head screws but #4 screws would work just fine. Start by drilling them top case holes to allow the hardware to slide in and then gently screw the screws into the base. https://www.shapeways.com/shops/rtd If you like this design and want to thank me my paypal address is [email protected] I can also do any customization.

Camera Mount for the HS1177M FPV Camera
This camera mount is designed to hold the HS1177M and to be printed with TPU. The Camera is held in by pressure from the ring around it. I offer three different angles, sorry they are all pretty aggressive (30-40degrees) but that's how I fly / race. 
Anything above 40 degrees you might as well use the regular HS1177 camera as this is so long.
I hold it to the frame with just double sided 3M tape. It works well for a while, eventually you need to apply new tape though.  
Once again, this is to be printed with TPU. If it is printed with ABS/PLA it won't hold the camera well.

These SouthPark Crew Spoonriders are inspired by the spoonriders of Julia Truchsess (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:146400).
Original SouthPark models were removed from Thingiverse apparently but can still be found here: https://cults3d.com/en/game/south-park-crew Support was optimized for easy 3D printing.

Notes: Print Kyle upside down

Step 1: Import South Park Crew model in Tinkercad
Step 2: Scale down (4-5 high cm is good size)
Step 3: Import the Spoonrider Hole (you can find it here: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8liGVHqyH4W-spoonrider-hole)
Step 4: Position the hole relative to the model
Step 5: Group the hole with the model. Then download for 3D printing.
